pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:0.5: The training rule on telling truthfully
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.2: At that time a number of monks who were friends had entered the rains on the banks of the river Vaggumudā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.3: Just then Vajjī was short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops blighted and turned to straw, and it was not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.4: The monks considered the difficult circumstances, and they thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.5: “How can we remain united and in harmony, have a comfortable rains, and get almsfood without problems?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.7: “We could do work for the lay people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.8: and they’ll give something in return.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.9: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rains in comfort and have no problems getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.11: “There’s no need to do work for the lay people.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.12: Let’s instead take messages for them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.13: and they’ll give something in return.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.14: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rains in comfort and have no problems getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.16: “There’s no need to do work for the lay people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.17: nor to take messages for them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.18: Let’s instead praise one another’s superhuman qualities to the lay people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.19: ‘Such a monk has the first absorption, such a monk the second absorption, such a monk the third, such a monk the fourth; such a monk is a stream-enterer, such a monk a once-returner, such a non-returner, such a perfected one; such a monk has the three true insights, and such the six direct knowledges.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.21: In this way we’ll be united and in harmony, and we’ll spend the rains in comfort and have no problems getting almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.22: Indeed, this is the better way, that we praise one another’s superhuman qualities to the lay people.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.23: Then they praised each other’s superhuman qualities to the lay people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.24: “Such a monk has the first absorption … such a monk has the six direct knowledges.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.26: “We’re fortunate that such monks have come to us for the rains. Such monks as these, who are virtuous and of good character, have never before entered the rains with us.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.27: And they gave such food and drink to those monks that they did not even eat and drink themselves, or give to their parents, to their wives and children, to their slaves, servants, and workers, to their friends and companions, or to their relatives.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.1.29: In this way those monks became handsome, with rounded features, bright faces, and clear skin.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.1: Now it was the custom for monks who had finished keeping the rains to go and see the Master.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.2: So when the rainy-season residence was completed and the three months had elapsed, those monks put their dwellings in order, took their bowls and robes, and departed for Vesālī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.3: When they eventually arrived at Vesālī, they went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.4: There they approached the Master, bowed down to him, and sat down to one side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.5: At that time the monks who had completed the rainy-season residence in that region were thin, haggard and pale, their veins protruding all over their limbs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.6: But the monks from the banks of the Vaggumudā were handsome, with rounded features, bright faces, and clear skin.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.7: It is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.8: and so the Master said to them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.9: “I hope you’re keeping well, monks, I hope you’re comfortable; I hope you spent the rains at ease, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and that you had no trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.11: we spent the rains at ease, in concord and harmony, without dispute, and we had no trouble getting almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.12: Buddhas sometimes ask knowing, and knowing sometimes do not ask;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.13: they ask knowing the right time to ask, and they ask knowing the right time not to ask.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.14: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.15: in regard to what is unbeneficial, the Buddhas have destroyed the bridge.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.16: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.17: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.18: And the Master said to those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.19: “In what way, monks, did you spend the rains at ease, without having any trouble getting almsfood?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.20: And they told the Master what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.21: “But had you really achieved those superhuman qualities?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.24: “Monks, how can you for the sake of your stomachs praise one another’s superhuman qualities to lay people?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.25: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.26: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:1.2.27: ‘If a monk truthfully tells a person who is not fully ordained of a superhuman quality, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is unchallengeable and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.1.6: anyone except a fully ordained monk and a fully ordained nun.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.7: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.8: “The monk who stayed in your dwelling attained the second absorption …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.9: the third absorption … the fourth absorption … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.11: has realized the fourth absorption,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.13: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.14: “The monk who stayed in your dwelling attained the emptiness release …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.15: the signless release … the desireless release … the emptiness stillness … the signless stillness … the desireless stillness … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.17: has realized the desireless stillness,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.19: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.20: “The monk who stayed in your dwelling attained the emptiness attainment …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.21: the signless attainment … the desireless attainment … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.23: has realized the desireless attainment,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.25: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.26: “The monk who stayed in your dwelling attained the three true insights …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.27: the four applications of mindfulness … the four right efforts … the four bases for supernormal power … the five spiritual faculties … the five spiritual powers … the seven factors of awakening … the noble eightfold path … the fruit of stream entry … the fruit of once-returning … the fruit of non-returning … perfection … is attaining … has attained … obtains … masters … has realized …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.28: has given up sensual desire … has given up ill-will … has given up confusion, renounced it, let it go, abandoned it, relinquished it, forsaken it, thrown it aside …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.29: has a mind free from the hindrance of sensual desire … has a mind free from the hindrance of ill-will … has a mind free from the hindrance of confusion,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.31: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.32: “The monk who stayed in your dwelling attained the first absorption in an empty dwelling …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.33: the second absorption … the third absorption … the fourth absorption … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.35: has realized the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.37: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.38: “The monk who made use of your robe-cloth … who made use of your almsfood … who made use of your dwelling … who made use of your medicines attained the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.40: has realized the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.42: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.43: “The monk who has made use of your dwelling … who has made use of your robe-cloth … who has made use of your almsfood … who has made use of your dwelling … who has made use of your medicines attained the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.45: has realized the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.47: if a monk says to a person who is not fully ordained,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.48: “The monk to whom you gave a dwelling … to whom you gave robe-cloth … to whom you gave almsfood … to whom you gave a dwelling … to whom you gave medicines … he attained the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling … is attaining … has attained …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.5.50: has realized the fourth absorption in an empty dwelling,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.6.2: if he truthfully tells one who is fully ordained;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.6.3: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc8:2.6.4: The eighth rule, the training rule on telling truthfully, is finished.
